author: Kristinn Viđar Thorbergsson

text:
I already knew about this opinion and philosophy. But, there is a key difference on what they have done to the iPhone 7.
In all previous changes, Apple tried to diss out the old techology to replace it with newer one that implemented new possibilities and seemed to be the right choice for a future common industry standard.

5" floppy -> 2.5" floppy  -> CD -> DVD -> USB

Parrallel / Serial -> Firewire (failed) -> USB -> USB C.

But with the iPhone the idea isn't the same, and here is the reason why.
Apple uses a PROPRIETARY connector on their phones and they do NOT intend on giving it up nor free it from the patent. I woudn't have bothered with the removal of the good ol' 3.5mm headphone jack IF they have dissed their lightnig connector for the new USB type C. Which seems to become the new industry standard, and would have allowed all companies to follow up.
The idea that Jobs talked about in this interview, we can see it with the developement of the MacBook. Which again dissed all connectors (USB A, mini DP, Lightning and power) for ONE USB type C. Francly i was happy when they have done that, but at the same NOT happy with the fact that it had only ONE of those connectors. Making a biger mess because it went against the idea of simplicty of using an apple product (because you need to use a ton of adapters).﻿

author: Samuel Irias

text:
When Apple got rid of the floppy, that was fine: it was too limited and better alternatives were becoming popular (CD-R, flash drives, sending files via internet). When Apple got rid of ADB, SCSI, and other connectors, that was fine: USB was more versatile and replaced all of them well enough.

But this is not fine. There is nothing wrong with the headphone jack. It provides better sound quality than Bluetooth. It doesn't require you to charge the headphones. It is immune to interference (if you try to use multiple Bluetooth devices at once, they can interfere with each other really bad, it just doesn't have much bandwidth). This move has one specific reason, and it is gouging their consumers.

Anyone with a modicum of self-respect should say now: fuck it, there are more honest alternatives, I'll go check them.﻿

author: WeMakeVideosCA

text:
With the removal of the headphone jack; 

People do not understand that, removing it is a bold and courageous move, and in conclusion was the right decision to make. If you sit down to think about the overall reasons and complaints, the reasons far outweigh the complaints.

There is no headphone jack; your only complaints can be:
1) form of connectivity for audio.
2) products that may no longer work 
3) change; which is what the human population dislikes for better or worse.

Now the reasons are so much better;
1) save of space, and removing what had a bad space:usefulness ratio.
2) Bluetooth will soon be perfected to better quality than the audio jack.
3) people may say they don't like bluetooth but look at the way of the world, all the places you use the audio jack (headphones, car, audio players/speakers), if you haven't realized we are moving to a wireless future; your car has bluetooth, your vcr is now a blu-ray player with Bluetooth, your headphones are now bose or beats...﻿
author: MrRarekiller10

text:
And those are wireless also, your computer can connect to other things with bluetooth, your wifi is wireless; everything is becoming wireless, and Apple is the only company bold enough to remove one of the last things requiring a wire. The next thing in the near future will be wireless charging on a mass and great scale. Soon we will no longer have ports for audio, charging, sim cards, memory (it will be in the cloud).

A wireless future is among us whether you like it or not.


(Just remember the life of the past products like cassette and CD players, vcr/dvd/and blu-ray taken over by digital, computers replaced by tablets and laptops... It's called moving forward. And i'm glad Apple is courageous enough to help us to do so whether we like it or not. We had bluetooth for years, that was your chance to adapt, now it's time to board the train, or get left behind.﻿

author: Samuel Tanner

text: Apple wasn't even the first company to remove the headphone jack. Nor were they the first company to make a phone with a dual lense camera. The problem you run into with removing the headphone jack is that the auxiliary input was a universal technology. Someone could just plug in their headphones into anyone's phone and play music. Now if you have an android with USB C headphones, someone with a headphone jack, and another with an iPhone 7, it just makes everything more complicated, needing more adapters, compared to when everything was so simple and universal. If Apple just switched to USB C, everything would become so simple again, from charging to listening to music and the removal of the headphone jack would become less of a burden for some. But we all know that will never happen.﻿

author: Brad Rodman

text:
CEOs of Major Corporations and people who just read youtube comments: 

If Steve wasn't so stubborn he would have been alive right now and he would have stopped the iPhone 7 from being such a bad phone. Although  I am an android user I think he would have helped apple from becoming the failing company it is now. Tim Cook should resign and be replaced by someone who knows what to look for and knows what they are doing (In a tech sense), I understand he used to be a developer but who ever is in control should know what tech is emerging or working, If a new technology could be implemented that IS better they should implement it slowly rather than going 0-100 like they did with the lightening port or firewire. USB type C is the victor in this situation and I do believe it may replace the 3mm Headphone jack but it will take time and some thought into how to listen and charge at the same time, Maybe wireless charging will take off and allow the user to charge and listen or maybe future phones will have 2 USB type C ports, but currently we just don't know. We have to wait for tech to be more fleshed out or offer both options (USBC and 3mm) like the Nexus line in order to fully get rid of one type of tech. It's kind of like foreplay you need to tease your partner (Customer) in order to continue to the fun (Implementing a new way of doing things) otherwise they're turned off. I understand being excited to show off new tech but it takes time.﻿

No, there is nothing special, hallowed, or irreplaceable about the 3.5mm connector. It's just another piece of technology. I haven't touched a 3.5mm cable for around 4 years. My Windows PC, my Android phones, my iPhone, my Lenovo laptop, my Amazon Fire HD... EVERY single piece of technology I own works with Bluetooth headphones. And I have some of the best Bluetooth headphones that exist, and they give me freedom from cables and introduce entire new use cases, like getting up and walking around while listening to a youtube video. I listen to audio on electronics devices for around 8 to 12 hours a day, and I haven't touched a 3.5mm connector for 4 years. It's not so much that the 3.5mm is universal; it's more that people are stuck in their ways and don't like to stomach having to try something new and spend more money to buy new accessories. 

Also, Apple wasn't even the first company to eliminate the 3.5mm headphone jack! The Moto Z Force released a few months ago was the first smartphone to market without the headphone jack. And there will be many more to come, now that Motorola and Apple have done it. The end is nigh for the 3.5mm jack; stop being a luddite and join the rest of society and upgrade. Or don't, and continue to use obsolete phones from the 2010s that still support the 3.5mm until the day you die. It makes no difference to me. Just don't complain when NEW technology comes out that excludes old, obsolete technology from the 1920s from its design.﻿

Was there a way for them to remove the headphone jack and come out of this on top? Absolutely. author: mrblob20

text: +aga1nst, How dumb are you? The audio from an audio jack is converted to analog inside the device using a DAC chip. And guess what? The same goes for Bluetooth wireless headphones. There is a chip inside that makes the digital signals analog. Our ears are analog. We cannot hear digital signals until they are converted to analog. The point is that the audio jack's digital to analog conversion is done inside the phone at the best bandwidth, as the signals never leave the circuitry of the phone. With Bluetooth, the signal is transmitted wirelessly before it is converted to analog. This hampers bandwidth, which is exactly what makes Bluetooth audio inferior. You seem to have no clue about audio at all, spouting absolute nonsense. But go ahead and convince yourself you are listening to 320kb/s digital streams, without any conversion to analog.﻿

Because it's a digital signal. And you know, I'm sure, that digitl signals have checksums and various other mechanisms to detect and eliminate noise. So yes - with the proper encoding algorithms bluetooth delivers crystal clear sound and it has all the bandwidth it needs to do that. Dumb moron.﻿

text: Daniël's Tech & Music Channel he problem with the analog cable is that the sound is transmitted in analog form, rther than digital, noise proof form as is the case with bluetooth. Sure it's converted back to analog but the analog signal would traver a fee millimeters instead of a few meters as is the case with the analog cable.﻿
author: aga1nst

text: +aga1nst The problem is that the analog cables deal fine with the current flowing through allowing for good audio fidelity, whereas Bluetooth bandwidth is too lackluster for good audio fidelity.﻿
author: Daniël's Tech & Music Channel

text: Daniël's Tech & Music Channel analog cables can handle the current but they are vulnerable to noise. Not that your ears can hear this noise but on theory there is some. While with digital signals you get the same signal. It's  not true that Bluetooth is lacking the bandwidth. It's not, especially if it's using aptx encoding - you can never hear a difference.﻿

author: MYT

text:
The controversy is not based on Apple changing the way they are powering headphones, it's based on them choosing a proprietary input jack. They could have chosen USB-C, which is open and well supported.

And while I don't disagree that the wireless technology is the future, good headphones require quite a bit of energy to power their drivers, and wireless technology just isn't capable of powering them for a reasonable duration.

Apple's business model and philosophy is to lock you into their ecosystem with proprietary hardware and software. Whether it is better or worse for the overall product does not matter.﻿

Peace.﻿

text: Wired is better than wireless in terms of quality. That's why the included headphones and the really expensive iphone headphones (think audeze not AirPods) are USB, which is far better quality than 3.5mm. You can't fit more than a 10 cent DAC in an iPhone because of size and heat constraints. If you really want quality you need a desktop DAC or A/V receiver. But you can fit a far better DAC in headphones than you can fit in a 1mmx1mm square in an iPhone.﻿
